revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Fort Flagler | nrhp_type = hd | nocat = yes | image = | caption = | coordinates = {{coord|48|5|50|N|122|41|41|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Washington | location = [[Jefferson County, Washington|Jefferson County]], SE of Port Townsend on [[Marrowstone Island]] | nearest_city =[[Port Townsend, Washington]] | area = | built = | architect = | architecture = | designated = | added = May 3, 1976 | established = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | refnum = 76001882 | mpsub = | governing_body = Washington State Parks and Recreation Commission }} '''Fort Flagler State Park''' is a [[List of Washington state parks|Washington state park]] on the site of '''Fort Flagler''', a former [[United States Army]] [[fort]] at the northern end of [[Marrowstone, Washington|Marrowstone Island]].
Fort Flagler was a [[United States Army Coast Artillery Corps|Coast Artillery]] fort. It was established in 1897 and activated on in 1899. The post was named for [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[Daniel Webster Flagler]], an [[American Civil War]] veteran who served as the Army's [[Ordnance Corps (United States Army)|Chief of Ordnance]]. The fort was closed in June 1953.<ref>Marge Mueller, Ted Mueller, [https://books.google.com/books?id=1wq1lfr271oC&pg=PA51&dq=%22fort+flagler%22+1899&hl=en&sa=X&ei=tZlAU4T0AcuysQSFn4DwDw&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22fort%20flagler%22%201899&f=false Washington State Parks: A Complete Recreation Guide], 2004, page 51</ref><ref>Richard E. Osborne, [https://books.google.com/books?id=sp_vAAAAMAAJ&q=%22fort+flagler%22+closed+1953&dq=%22fort+flagler%22+closed+1953&hl=en&sa=X&ei=k5pAU5e8GtPfsAS9uYKoBg&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBTgK World War II Sites in the United States: A Tour Guide & Directory], 1996, page 278</ref><ref>Washington State Adjutant General, [https://books.google.com/books?id=jbHlAAAAMAAJ&q=%22fort+flagler%22+%22daniel+webster+flagler%22&dq=%22fort+flagler%22+%22daniel+webster+flagler%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PZtAU-7VOeTQsQSam4AY&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAg The Official History of the Washington National Guard: Washington National Guard in World War I], 1961, page 454</ref>
From Fort Flagler State Park, visitors can see [[Port Townsend]] to the northwest, the cranes at the [[United States Navy|Navy]] base on [[Indian Island, Washington|Indian Island]] to the west, and [[Whidbey Island]] eastward across [[Admiralty Inlet]]. Flagler Road (SR 116) terminates inside the park.
==Amenities and activities== [[Image:Flagler1.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Green being "mowed" outside of former officers' homes at Fort Flagler State Park.]] [[Image:Flagler2.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Kite flying on the parade ground at Fort Flagler State Park. The hospital building (left) and one of the current ranger residences (middle) can be seen in the background.]] Fort Flagler has hiking and biking trails, individual campsites suitable for cars, two group campsites, two boat launches, and several historical buildings where visitors can stay - the Hospital Steward's House, the Waterway House, and the North and South [[Non-Commissioned Officer|Non-Commissioned Officers']] Quarters.
The park's museum features exhibits about the history of the fort. Guided tours of the historic fort buildings can be arranged in advance.
From 1958 to 1989 it was home to the [[Seattle Youth Symphony]]'s Pacific Northwest Music Camp and [[Marrowstone Music Festival]] every August. A film "1812 Overture" was filmed on location there in 1974.
Every August, the [[Kamiak High School|Kamiak]] Show Band holds its annual "band camp," during which band members learn new music, prepare for the upcoming marching band season, and rehearse in sessions enjoyed by members of the visiting public.
[[Newport High School (Bellevue, Washington)]] also holds a cross-country camp at Fort Flagler for one week during the summer.
[[Eastside Catholic High School]] juniors and seniors take a trip to Fort Flagler for the Destiny retreat.
[[Seattle Girls Choir]] has their annual "Choir Camp" during the first weekend in August. This is a time for all three of the upper level choirs to have intensive music instruction in an environment that is fun and enjoyable
United Methodist Youth from the Seattle/Tacoma district enjoy a weekend retreat there in mid-late fall.
The [[neo-pagan]] [[Aquarian Tabernacle Church]] performs a modern [[Eleusinian Mysteries]] play here over [[Easter]] weekend each year.
